raw_text: Second, recent work by Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) has induced? narrative chains? ,i.e., likely sequences of events, by their use of similar head words

citing_paper_authors: Preethi, Raghavan | Eric, Fosler-Lussier | NoÃ©mie, Elhadad | Albert M., Lai
raw_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) describe a process to inducea partially ordered set of events related by a common protagonist by using an unsupervised distributional method to learn relations between events sharing co referring arguments, followed by temporal classification to induce partial order
clean_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) describe a process to induce a partially ordered set of events related by a common protagonist by using an unsupervised distributional method to learn relations between events sharing co referring arguments, followed by temporal classification to induce partial order.

raw_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009, 2008) propose an unsupervised method for learning narrative schemas, chains of events whose arguments are filled with participant semantic roles defined over words
clean_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009, 2008) propose an unsupervised method for learning narrative schemas, chains of events whose arguments are filled with participant semantic roles defined over words.

raw_text: Inspired by Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) we acquire story plots automatically by recording events, their participants, and their precedence relationships as at tested in a training corpus
clean_text: Inspired by Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) we acquire story plots automatically by recording events, their participants, and their precedence relationships as at tested in a training corpus.
Our narrative schemas differ slightly from Chambers and Jurafsky (2009).

raw_text: Another generative model for SRL has been proposed in (Thompson et al, 2003), but the parameters were estimated from fully annotated data. The unsupervised setting has also been cons id ering for the related problem of learning narrative schemas (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009)
clean_text: The unsupervised setting has also been considering for the related problem of learning narrative schemas (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009).

raw_text: Our previous work (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009) learned situation-specific roles over narrative schemas, similar to frame roles in FrameNet (Baker et al, 1998)
clean_text: Our previous work (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009) learned situation-specific roles over narrative schemas, similar to frame roles in FrameNet (Baker et al, 1998).

raw_text: inducing narrative schemas (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009) may beviewed as a possible next step in a narrative induction pipeline, subsequent to disentangling the text comprising individual narrative threads
clean_text: Inducing narrative schemas (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009) may be viewed as a possible next step in a narrative induction pipeline, subsequent to disentangling the text comprising individual narrative threads.

raw_text: Similar observations can be made with respect to Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) and Kasch and Oates (2010), who also study a single discourse relation (narration), and are thus more limited in scope than the approach described here
clean_text: Similar observations can be made with respect to Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) and Kasch and Oates (2010), who also study a single discourse relation (narration), and are thus more limited in scope than the approach described here.

raw_text: It thus represents the basis for further experiments ,e.g., with respect to the enrichment the BKB with information provided by Riaz and Girju (2010), Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) and Kasch and Oates (2010)
clean_text: It thus represents the basis for further experiments, e.g., with respect to the enrichment the BKB with information provided by Riaz and Girju (2010), Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) and Kasch and Oates (2010).

citing_paper_authors: Eric T., Nalisnick | Henry S., Baird
raw_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) described a system that can learn (without supervision) the sequence of events described in a narrative, and Elson and McKeown (2009 )createda platform that can symbolically represent and reason over narratives. Narrative structure has also been studied by representing character interactions as networks
clean_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) described a system that can learn (without supervision) the sequence of events described in a narrative, and Elson and McKeown (2009) created a platform that can symbolically represent and reason over narratives. Narrative structure has also been studied by representing character interactions as networks.

citing_paper_authors: Joseph, Irwin | Mamoru, Komachi | Yuji, Matsumoto
raw_text: Our system is based on a cluster-ranking model proposed by Rahman and Ng (2009), with novel semantic features based on recent re search on narrative event schema (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009)
clean_text: Our system is based on a cluster-ranking model proposed by Rahman and Ng (2009), with novel semantic features based on recent research on narrative event schema (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009).

citing_paper_authors: Enrique, Alfonseca | Daniele, Pighin | Guillermo, Garrido
raw_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) present an unsupervised method for learning narrative schemas from news ,i.e., coherent sets of events that involve specific entity types (semantic roles)
clean_text: Chambers and Jurafsky (2009) present an unsupervised method for learning narrative schemas from news, i.e., coherent sets of events that involve specific entity types (semantic roles).

raw_text: McIntyre and Lapata (2010) create a story generation system that draws on earlier work on narrative schemas (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009)
clean_text: McIntyre and Lapata (2010) create a story generation system that draws on earlier work on narrative schemas (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009).

citing_paper_authors: David, McClosky | Mihai, Surdeanu | Christopher D., Manning
clean_text: Event structures in open domain texts are frequently highly complex and nested: a "crime" event can cause an "investigation" event, which can lead to an "arrest"event (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2009).
